question:
It is more important for a building to serve a purpose than to look beautiful. Architects shouldn’t worry about producing building as a work of art.

Do you agree or disagree?
text: In this day and age, whether constructing buildings to cater for the basic needs or the aesthetic needs of people has sparked a heated debate. I am of the opinion that it had better strike a happy medium between the workability and beauty of the constructions.

Compelling arguments can be proposed that there are myriad merits to the notion that accommodations should afford the fundamental requirements of their settlers. In the first place, Considering the need for shelter according to the pyramid needs of humans, houses have to offer the highest level of safety. Essentially, whatever your house is beautiful if you suffer from the lack of safety it would be good-for-noting. In the second place, more gorgeous structures have more cost of maintenance. ,Consequently excessively attaching emphasis on having more handsome buildings people's affordability can be lowered. Finally yet importantly, the main and foremost purpose of purchasing a house is nothing but relief, convenience, and security that just can be provided by indoor facilities rather than the glamorous facade of the building. In fact, the most glamorous facade would be a merely significant contribution to the beauty of the neighbourhood and the city  serving no purpose regarding the peace, convenience, and comfort of the residents.

On the other hand, improving the cityscapes is directly contingent on how much time architectures expend on beautifying the buildings. Although some purposes like safety, security, and convenient amenities should be received the top precedence, it is undeniable that the beautiful surface of the building or architectural interior design can make people feel refreshed, and rejuvenated. For example, exercising different architectural designs or some periodical renovation in the construction are highly required to take settlers' minds off the monotonous interior and exterior design; Therefore, discounting the significance of architecture to the beauty of the buildings and pursuing lifelong accommodation in an awful house comes about with nothing other than depression, contrary to the sustainability that would be guaranteed by attaching rational remark to architecture artworks in every place of houses.
In conclusion, having considered the above-mentioned arguments, I am convinced that having houses well-balanced in terms of captivating beauty and amenities makes life more sustainable.
